sections.text:
Annals of Botany 81 : 687–696, 1998
BOTANICAL BRIEFING
Fire, Forest Regeneration and Links with Early Human Habitation: Evidence from New Zealand
JOHN OGDEN*, LES BASHER† and MATT McGLONE†
*School of En ironmental and Marine Sciences, Uni ersity of Auckland, New Zealand and †Landcare Research,
Lincoln, New Zealand
Received: 14 November 1997 Returned for revision: 1 January 1998 Accepted: 19 March 1998
New Zealand forests burn less frequently than tussock grasslands, heath or shrublands. Species composition, past disturbance and stand condition determine inflammability and fuel load, and consequent fire intensity and spatial extent. Before people arrived, fires were ignited by lightning during drought years on the eastern sides of both islands. Volcanism occurring every 300–600 years was associated with fires in the central North Island. A review of radiocarbon-dated charcoal from the eastern South Island, and of evidence for fire in pollen profiles from the North Island, provide the basis for an assessment of fire frequency. Forest fires have occurred on both New Zealand’s islands throughout the Holocene at least every few centuries, until the last millennium when frequency increased. The ‘return time’ of fire at any one place in the forested landscape was probably one or two millennia. Burned areas usually succeeded to forest again before the next inflagration. Consequently fire adaptation is infrequent in the New Zealand flora, and Polynesian forest clearance was rapid and largely permanent. There is an indication of an increase in fire frequency in the late Holocene, and a clear signal associated with people approx. 700 years BP. Separating the earliest anthropogenic fires from the background level of natural burning will be difficult without additional evidence.

Key words : Fire history, New Zealand, palynology, Maori, climate, volcanism.

sections.heading: INTRODUCTION
sections.text:
The Gondwanic floras of Australia and South Africa have evolved community types in which fire adaptations are frequent (Jackson, 1968; Noble and Slatyer, 1981; Wheelan, 1995; Bond and van Wilgen, 1996; Kershaw et al., 1997). This has not happened to the same extent in New Zealand, which is an isolated fragment of Gondwana in temperate latitudes, mostly between 35 and 45° S. New Zealand has a wetter, more maritime climate and was colonized by people much more recently than the larger southern continents. Most of the pre-Polynesian landscape of New Zealand was clothed in temperate rain-forest (Fig. 1A). With a few exceptions, New Zealand tree species are killed by fire; they neither resprout from lignotubers or epicormic buds, nor benefit by post-fire seedling establishment from buried or shed seeds. When fire does occur in these forests the original vegetation is destroyed, and a prolonged succession begins, taking centuries to regain the former structure and composition. Consequently, despite obvious natural ignition sources—lightning and volcanism—and some unequivocal evidence for Holocene fires (Molloy et al., 1963), the predominant view amongst New Zealand plant ecologists has been that the forests were rarely burned prior to the arrival of people (Burrows, 1990; Wardle, 1991).
Lack of fire adaptations, and long successional recovery periods for forest, are assumed to explain why fires set by Polynesian (Maori) colonists approx. 700 years ago rapidly eliminated forest over large areas of the lowlands (McGlone,
1983). A consequence of this removal is that we can no longer directly study the natural frequency or dynamics of fire in those forest ecosystems which were, presumably, the most inflammable. The remaining forest tracts are largely in higher rainfall areas where ignition is less probable.
People probably arrived in New Zealand somewhere between 2000 and 850 years BP, with proponents of the earlier date arguing largely from interpretation of pollen and charcoal in lake sediments (Sutton, 1987, 1994), and from radiocarbon dates on bone gelatin from Pacific rats (Rattus exulans) (Holdaway, 1996). Despite criticism of the palynological interpretations (Enright and Osborne, 1988) and the rat dates (Anderson, 1996), and the lack of archaeological evidence in New Zealand before approx. 850 years BP, the older date has been widely accepted as ‘fact ’ by the public press, further polarizing views within the scientific community (Anderson, 1996). Consequently, the time is appropriate for a review of the evidence for natural fires and a discussion of how these might differ in frequency or extent from those due to people.
We begin by outlining the factors which predispose New Zealand vegetation types to fire, and examining the frequency of natural events capable of igniting forest. Emphasis is on forest communities although the mosaic of heathland, grassland, swamp and forest across the landscape obviously influences the chance of fire occurring, its intensity and spread. We then review the spatial and temporal occurrence of fire by analysis of radiocarbon dates on macroscopic charcoal and buried logs (South Island), and

sections.heading: OF FIRE IN THE MAIN VEGETATION TYPES
sections.text:
Different vegetation types have different susceptibility to fire, and different fire frequencies and intensities. Interactions between the climatic regime, soil type and topography are all involved, as these features determine both the vegetation type, the likelihood of fire, and the probability that it will spread.
Non-forest communities
Shrublands and heaths include the most fire-prone of New Zealand community types, and contain some fireadapted species (e.g. Leptospermum scoparium, Esler and Astridge, 1974; Burrows et al., 1979; Enright, 1989). Vegetation consisting of shrubby conifers (Phyllocladus alpinus, Halocarpus biforme, H. bidwilli), Dracophyllum spp., Hebe spp. and Asteraceae shrubs currently occurs close to tree-line and in the sub-alpine zone and was more widespread in lowland areas in the early post-glacial period. Fires have been recorded in sub-alpine heathlands in the
central North Island (e.g. Rogers and McGlone, 1994; Ogden et al., 1997), and most of the early Holocene charcoal in the South Island is Phyllocladus. Significantly, this is one of the few New Zealand conifers capable of basal resprouting following damage to the main stem.
Tussock grasslands carry a large amount of dead biomass as leaf bases and sheaths, which predisposes them to fire. Fires promote vegetative growth, flowering and seed germination. These communities can withstand fires with a return time of a few decades (Calder et al., 1992; Mark, 1994). The extensive literature on the role of fire in the South Island tussock grasslands was reviewed by Basher, Meurk and Tate (1990) and Allen, Basher and Comrie (1995).
Lowland wetlands often carry a high vegetation biomass and can dry out sufficiently to carry fires, which have been recorded on peat bogs (e.g. Newnham, De Lange and Lowe, 1995), ‘pakihi ’ (Williams et al., 1990) and other wetlands (Timmins, 1992; Clarkson, 1997). Palynological studies are mainly located in wetlands and may contain good records of local fires.

sections.heading: Forests
sections.text:
The present forests of New Zealand can be divided into three broad formations: beech forest, dominated by trees in the genus Nothofagus and largely southern and montane in distribution; kauri forest, containing the large conifer Agathis australis and restricted to the north of North
Island; and a plethora of other forest types containing members of the family Podocarpaceae and angiosperms, which can be grouped as podocarp}hardwood forest. About 70% of the area of New Zealand has been cleared of these forests by human use of fire (Fig. 1A–C).
The proportions of forest and the more inflammable heathland and tussock grasslands on the New Zealand landscape have varied considerably since the Last Glacial Maximum, when most of the montane and lowland regions south of Auckland carried tussock grasslands and scrub. Extensive loess deposits, and other evidence, imply a cold, relatively dry and windy climate. As the climate became warmer and wetter in post-glacial time, forest dominated by podocarps spread rapidly over both islands. These forests increased in diversity and reached their maximum extent during the period 10000–7000 years BP, which probably had a more equable climate than the present (McGlone, 1988). After this, increased climatic extremes appear to have led to more disturbance on the landscape, favouring the spread of Agathis australis in the north, and Nothofagus in the southern mountains. Thus, the relative proportions of the major plant formations have not been static, and this fact must be considered in the context of the history of fires.
Most areas of forest in New Zealand are subject to occasional widespread disturbances causing tree mortality (Shaw, 1983; Ogden et al., 1993b ; Ogden, Stewart and Allen, 1996; Wilmshurst, McGlone and Partridge, 1997). These events result in new cohorts of regenerating trees, which reach senility more or less synchronously some centuries later. Collapse of the old cohort, triggered by some environmental stress, perpetuates the pattern (Ogden and Stewart, 1995). Synchronous forest die-back also occurs for other reasons, especially during droughts, following defoliation by insects, or as a result of volcanic ash-fall. Senile cohorts with abundant dead wood may be more prone to ignition than younger regenerating phases, and will carry a more intense fire once ignited. Synchronous death of seral Kunzea ericoides populations inputs highly inflammable standing dead timber into young Agathis forests, increasing the probability of ignition. Massive germination of Kunzea commonly occurs following fire, leading to almost pure stands, or mixtures with Leptospermum which may perpetuate the fire cycle. The ignition frequency and the mosaic of Leptospermum, Kunzea, and young and old Agathis forest present on theNorthern landscape, are thus inter-dependent.
Agathis australis produces large quantities of highly inflammable resin (‘gum’) and the forest carries a large wood volume, including other inflammable species (Phyllocladus spp., Halocarpus spp., Dracophyllum spp.) (Table 1). Moreover, the slowly decomposing litter of Agathis and associated sclerophyllous gymnosperms accumulates beneath the trees (Enright and Ogden, 1987). Extensive fires occurred during the early exploitation of these forests by Europeans. The burned areas were mostly quickly colonized by Leptospermum scoparium which acted as a ‘nurse’ for the re-establishment of Phyllocladus and Agathis (Ogden and Stewart, 1995). The relatively rapid re-establishment of young Agathis forests following burning suggests a degree of tolerance to occasional intense and widespread fires (Esler and Astridge, 1974).
In contrast, Nothofagus forests have a relatively low wood volume, and a higher mineral content in the leaves and wood. There are few associated tree species. When gymnosperms do occur they are usually scattered individuals. Nothofagus litter decomposes relatively quickly. Although some fires set by Europeans have burned Nothofagus forests (McQueen, 1951; Wiser, Allen and Platt, 1997) and there is abundant Holocene evidence of fires in the form of Nothofagus charcoal, Nothofagus forest may be more difficult to ignite, and less likely to carry a fire, than Agathis forest. Despite this, extensive areas of Nothofagus forest in drier areas have been transformed into tussock grassland by fire. Nothofagus recolonization is slow because any Nothofagus seedlings that manage to establish despite the thick sward and dense root mat of grasses are more susceptible to frost and summer drought than those occurring in shrubland or forest gaps (McGlone, Mildenhall and Pole, 1996).
Podocarp-hardwood forests tend to be intermediate between Agathis and Nothofagus forest in terms of structure and species diversity, and probably also in their intrinsic flammability. However, these forest types (now) characterize the wetter montane zones, where fires appear to be infrequent. The dominant gymnosperm (Dacrydium cupressinum) has many of the fire-promoting and fire-tolerating characteristics of Agathis, and dense stands frequently develop on old Maori burn sites (McKelvey, 1963). Succession following fire often involves Weinmannia racemosa, which is less prone to re-burning than is Leptospermum scoparium (Payton, Allen and Knowlton, 1984). Podocarpus- and Prumnopitys- dominated forests in the eastern foothills of the Southern Alps and in Marlborough were eliminated by Polynesian fires, and similar forests in the rain-shadow areas of the North Island were destroyed by fires after the Taupo eruption (approx. 1718 BP; Sparks et al., 1995; Wilmshurst and McGlone, 1996), or during European times (Elder, 1962).

sections.heading: Drought frequency
sections.text:
Drought is the key factor predisposing forest to ignition by lightning. The pattern of burning during forest clearance by Maori approx. 700 years BP reflected rainfall patterns more than the suitability for settlement of the burned areas (McGlone, 1983). Drier eastern parts of the country, and the lowlands, were burned while the wetter west and montane zones were less affected. This pattern can be seen in the rainfall map of New Zealand, where the 1600 mm isohyet separates largely unforested from largely forested areas (Fig. 1D).
Summer drought is a regular feature of the lowlands of New Zealand, especially in eastern rain-shadow areas. Severe droughts are probably more common during strong El Nino years, but occur whenever the Southern Oscillation Index (ENSO) is either strongly positive or strongly negative (McGlone, Kershaw and Markgraf, 1992). Foehn winds, blowing across the Canterbury Plains from the Southern Alps, predispose the vegetation to burning. Droughts occurred in Canterbury on average every 2 years between 1900 and 1950 (Burrows and Greenland, 1979). In the

sections.heading: NATURAL SOURCES OF IGNITION—LIGHTNING AND VOLCANISM
sections.text:
Electric storms are not frequent in New Zealand, and are usually associated with troughs moving east from the Tasman Sea (Tomlinson, 1976). Consequently most lightning occurs in western districts, where up to 20 electric storms may occur per annum. Such storms bring heavy rainfall and are unlikely to result in fires, although there is evidence that this happened occasionally in pre-Polynesian times in Westland (Burrows et al., 1979). Lightning is less frequent in eastern districts where it is usually a consequence of convectional uplift during dry periods in summer (Fig. 1D). About 2000 wildfires occur each year in New Zealand, mostly in ‘scrub’ or tussock grasslands. About forty of these are caused by lightning (S. M. Timmins, pers. comm.).

Summer lightning during drought periods is the probable cause of pre-Maori fires in Otago and the Canterbury Plains, and in the eastern ranges of the North Island (Rogers and McGlone, 1989).
Volcanic eruptions can cause fires by direct ignition from red-hot magma or ash close to the vent, and by electric storms created by the intense convection. Forest mortality associated with the blast, or with ash-fall or acid rain, may also cause surrounding areas to be susceptible to fire in the period following a large eruption.
There is evidence that fires continued for at least a century after the Taupo eruption of approx. 1718 BP (Wilmshurst and McGlone, 1996), even in regions where the forest was not initially devastated (Newnham et al., 1995). Presumably forest damaged by the eruption accumulated a large dead wood fuel load which was relatively easily ignited, or there was an increase in the area covered by more inflammable seral heathlands, or both.
During the last 50000 years, active volcanoes have deposited tephras over the whole of the North Island (Table 2) with an average rate of one widespread tephra deposition event every 370 years in the last 17000 years (Lowe, 1988). Volcanism has probably caused widespread fires in the
central North Island with a return time of 300–600 years during this time.

Radiocarbondates on buried charcoal (mostlyNothofagus and Podocarpaceae) in South Island soils have accumulated since Molloy et al.’s (1963) seminal paper. The total data base now comprises 169 radiocarbon dates, mostly from macroscopic soil charcoal in stratigraphic sites. The results (Figs 2 and 3A) confirm both the widespread evidence for pre-Polynesian fires in the eastern forests, and deforestation by fire during the last 1000 years.
Fires occurred inmost centuries throughout the Holocene. There were some older charcoals (back to approx. 50000 years BP) but the paucity of glacial-aged charcoal (not included in Fig. 3A) probably relates both to the much reduced forest cover at that time (McGlone, 1988) and to loss of material through erosion. Interpreted as a fire history, the data may be biased in favour of younger deposits.
‘Fire interval ’, as used here, is the average time between sequentially dated charcoal samples, and measures how common charcoal deposits of various ages are throughout the eastern South Island, A short fire interval implies a high fire frequency. Five distinct fire interval frequencies can be recognized. For much of the Holocene, fires occurred with an interval measured in centuries (approx. 200 years ; Fig.
3A). After approx. 3000 years BP there was an almost fourfold increase in fire frequency, perhaps due to more frequent droughts associated with intensification of El Nino circulation patterns (McGlone et al., 1992). Another peak occurred approx. 1000 years BP. The strongest peak was between 700–500 years BP, when the fire interval was less than a decade. Finally, a peak between 240 and 60 years BP is due to European activity.
The fire ‘return time’ at any one site is greater than the fire interval as defined here. Return time shows great variability with a frequency peak in the 1500–2000 year interval and a median of approx. 2000 years based on seven sites where more than one fire was recorded. Most areas would therefore return to forest before re-burning.
The 700–500 years BP charcoal peak coincides with similar evidence for Maori fires in the North Island. The earlier peak (approx. 1000 years BP) emphasizes one of the problems in interpreting radiocarbon dates from charcoal ; it could represent an earlier peak of Maori burning, but more likely arises from the burning of older trees in mature forest during the 700–500 years BP period (i.e. ‘ inbuilt age’ effect). Many New Zealand gymnosperms reach ages of 600–1000 years, while canopy angiosperms are often 300–500 years old. Charcoal derived from such forest could thus be older than the fire by many centuries.

These sorts of data, discussed by McGlone (1983, 1989) and Newnham et al. (1997), document widespread Polynesian burning commencing about the time of the Kaharoa Tephra (665³15 years BP; Lowe et al., 1988) or possibly up to two centuries earlier (Elliot et al., 1995). Whatever the date of the anthropogenic charcoal peak, it differs from earlier peaks in its sustained nature, and by its associations with a marked rise in Pteridium spores. Pteridium is favoured by repeated burning, and its rhizomes were used as a staple food by Maori. Other palynological indicators of anthropogenic forest clearance at this time include increased grass pollen, and some seral species (Weinmannia, Coriaria), and a sharp decline in forest tree taxa (Nothofagus, Dacrydium). The evidence for Maori burning over wide areas of the North Island since approx. 650 years BP is unequivocal ; whether or not earlier fires can be ascribed to people is a matter of debate (Sutton, 1987, 1994; Enright and Osborne, 1988; Newnham et al., 1997).
Newnham et al. (1995) presented a charcoal curve from Kopuatai Bog in the Waikato Basin, interpreting peaks as representing discrete fires (Fig. 3B). Before 6000 years BP, fires were 800–1500 years apart, but after that increased in frequency to an interval of approx. 100–200 years. However, the data could indicate a gradual increase in fire frequency throughout the Holocene, with peaks associated with tephra deposits. As usual in palynological profiles from throughout New Zealand, the highest charcoal percentages were in the post-Maori period (after 700 years BP) when the fire interval declined to an estimated 78 years.
North Island studies of stratigraphic sequences including charcoal evidence are summarized in Figs 2 and 4. The number of publications progressively declines as the time span is lengthened, but the results indicate fires throughout the Holocene in the North Island. Six publications purport to include the Last Glacial Maximum (" 16000–20000 years BP), when there is evidence of fires in about half the studies (Newnham, 1992; Striewski et al., 1996). The mean proportion of studies reporting fires is no different before and after 10000 BP (Fig. 4B), although there is a suggestion of a peak in the late glacial (approx. 13–14000 years BP). Generally high proportions from approx. 14000 to 7000 years BP are interrupted by a low from 8–9000 years BP, but these ‘ trends’ are based on few studies and are reported tentatively. The apparent rise since approx. 7000 BP is based on more publications and probably reflects a real increase in fire frequency. All publications covering the last 1000 years record evidence of fire during this millennium, in confirmation of anthropogenic forest clearance.

sections.heading: DISCUSSION AND CONCLUSIONS
sections.text:
The charcoal evidence from the eastern South Island indicates that fires were a regular feature of the plains and foothills long before those lit by early Maori. In the North Island there is also evidence of fire in every millennium since the last Glacial Maximum. Conditions conducive to fire in forest currently occur at least once per decade in the eastern lowlands of New Zealand and probably several times per century, even in the mountains. Throughout the Holocene, ignition by lightning probably occurred every few centuries in the east and the Far North, where some of the most inflammable communities occur. Over a large proportion of
the North Island, fires were also either started by volcanic eruptions, or followed them as a consequence of the increased flammability of the damaged forests and seral shrublands.
The data from which the fire histories of the South and North Islands have been constructed are fundamentally different, making them difficult to compare. In the South we have the frequency of charred wood in soils, while in the North the data relate to the proportion of (palynological) studies recording microscopic charcoal at different depths. The charcoal increase after approx. 3000 years BP in the South Island, and the apparent rise in fire frequency since approx. 7000 years BP in the North Island data, both imply a late Holocene pre-human increase in burning, perhaps associated with intensified ENSO circulation (McGlone et al., 1992). The late Holocene extension of Agathis southwards, commencing approx. 7000 years BP (Ogden et al., 1992) may have been facilitated by a change to more variable climatic conditions, especially droughts, causing an increase in fire frequency.
Although extensive forest fires probably occurred every few centuries on both islands, fires at any one place appear to have been a millennium or two apart. Before people dramatically changed the fire regime, the landscape comprised a mosaic of seral communities within a mature forest matrix, and fire adaptation was favoured only in those species capable also of surviving long fire-free periods.
Figure 3A illustrates the difficulty of using charcoal to differentiate the first anthropogenic fires from those of a natural origin. The 1000 year peak is only approx. 300 years before a period when there is abundant evidence of people in New Zealand, and an anthropogenic interpretation could also be supported by Holdaway’s (1996) rat dates. However, the rat dates may be flawed (Anderson, 1996) and the initial burning of old-growth forest would produce much charcoal 300 or more years older than the fire (inbuilt age effect). If charcoal increase alone is made the criterion for the presence of people, then the 3000 year increase in Fig. 3B could also be so ascribed, but this date is before Polynesian colonization of the Central Pacific.
The crucial difference between natural and anthropogenic fire may be that the latter is purposeful ; to clear the land of forest for access, hunting, or agriculture. To achieve the purpose repeated burning is required, preventing succession to forest and leading to permanent vegetation change. Only a dramatic increase in charcoal, associated with evidence of soil instability and}or forest replacement by herbaceous communities (especially Pteridium and grass), indicates fires lit by people (McGlone and Wilmshurst, 1997).
In a recent review, Newnham et al. (1997) show that all the best dated sustained charcoal and Pteridium increases in North Island pollen diagrams were made after approx. 700 years BP, thus favouring the ‘short prehistory model ’ of Anderson (1991). Earlier fires without a sustained Pteridium rise could have been due to people at a very low density, although it can be argued that fire frequency is not closely related to population density (McGlone and Wilmshurst, 1997). It will probably be impossible to separate the first anthropogenic fires from the background level of natural burning documented here. However, the date of significant
human impact in any area can be discerned from the charcoal data.

abstractText: New Zealand forests burn less frequently than tussock grasslands, heath or shrublands. Species composition, past disturbance and stand condition determine inflammability and fuel load, and consequent fire intensity and spatial extent. Before people arrived, fires were ignited by lightning during drought years on the eastern sides of both islands. Volcanism occurring every 300–600 years was associated with fires in the central North Island. A review of radiocarbon-dated charcoal from the eastern South Island, and of evidence for fire in pollen profiles from the North Island, provide the basis for an assessment of fire frequency. Forest fires have occurred on both New Zealand’s islands throughout the Holocene at least every few centuries, until the last millennium when frequency increased. The ‘return time’ of fire at any one place in the forested landscape was probably one or two millennia. Burned areas usually succeeded to forest again before the next inflagration. Consequently fire adaptation is infrequent in the New Zealand flora, and Polynesian forest clearance was rapid and largely permanent. There is an indication of an increase in fire frequency in the late Holocene, and a clear signal associated with people approx. 700 years BP. Separating the earliest anthropogenic fires from the background level of natural burning will be difficult without additional evidence. # 1998 Annals of Botany Company
title: BOTANICAL BRIEFING. Fire, Forest Regeneration and Links with Early Human Habitation: Evidence from New Zealand
